Submodules

endemo2.data_structures.containers module

This module contains all simple data containers used in endemo.

class Demand(electricity=0, heat=None, hydrogen=0, fuel=0)[source]

Bases: object

A container for the amount of demand split into different categories. Provides arithmetic operations.

Parameters:

  • electricity (float) – Amount of electricity demand.

  • heat (Heat) – Amount of heat demand.

  • hydrogen (float) – Amount of hydrogen demand.

  • fuel (float) – Amount of fuel demand (only transport sector).

Variables:

  • electricity (float) – Amount of electricity demand.

  • heat (Heat) – Amount of heat demand.

  • hydrogen (float) – Amount of hydrogen demand.

  • fuel (float) – Amount of fuel demand.

class Heat(q1=0, q2=0, q3=0, q4=0)[source]

Bases: object

  • q2 (float) – Amount for heat level Q2

  • q3 (float) – Amount for heat level Q3

  • q4 (float) – Amount for heat level Q4

Variables:

  • q2 (float) – Amount for heat level Q2

  • q3 (float) – Amount for heat level Q3

  • q4 (float) – Amount for heat level Q4

endemo2.data_structures.conversions_unit module

This module holds any information and utility functions related to unit conversion.

class Unit(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enum for any unity that are used in the model.

Billion = 10
GJ = 5
GWh = 1
MJ = 13
MWh = 2
Million = 9
PJ = 12
Standard = 8
TJ = 4
TWh = 0
kWh = 3
kilo = 11
liter = 6
m3 = 7
convert(from_unit, to_unit, value)[source]

Converts a value from one unit to another.

Parameters:

  • from_unit (Unit) – The unit the input value is.

  • to_unit (Unit) – The unit the output value should be

  • value (float) – The value to convert.

Return type:

float

Returns:

The converted value.

get_conversion_scalar(from_unit, to_unit)[source]

Get the scalar that converts one unit to another.

Parameters:

  • from_unit (Unit) – The unit of the value that should be converted.

  • to_unit (Unit) – The resulting unit.

Return type:

float

Returns:

The scalar for unit conversion.

endemo2.data_structures.enumerations module

This module contains all Enums of endemo.

class DemandType(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enum to easily differentiate the type of demand.

ELECTRICITY = 0
FUEL = 3
HEAT = 1
HYDROGEN = 2
class ForecastMethod(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

The ForecastMethod indicates the preferred way to extrapolate historical data.

Variables:

  • LINEAR – The forecast method utilizing linear regression.

  • QUADRATIC – The forecast method utilizing quadratic regression.

  • EXPONENTIAL – The forecast method utilizing exponential growth.

  • QUADRATIC_OFFSET – The forecast method utilizing quadratic regression and an additional offset.

EXPONENTIAL = 2
LINEAR = 0
LOGARITHMIC = 4
QUADRATIC = 1
QUADRATIC_OFFSET = 3
class GroupType(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

Enum to differentiate different country group types.

Variables:

  • SEPARATE – All countries in this type of group are calculated separately.

  • JOINED – The data of all countries in a group of type joined is lumped together and shared coefficients are calculated.

  • JOINED_DIVERSIFIED – The data of all countries in a group of type joined_diversified is lumped together and shared coefficients are calculated. But each country has a differing offset additionally.

  • EMPTY – Indicates that no group type is chosen.

EMPTY = 3
JOINED = 1
JOINED_DIVERSIFIED = 2
SEPARATE = 0
class HouseholdsSubsectorId(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

The enum class to quickly recognise the different household sectors.

COOKING = (3,)
LIGHTING_AND_APPLIANCES = 4
OTHER = 5
SPACE_COOLING = (1,)
SPACE_HEATING = (0,)
WATER_HEATING = (2,)

Bases: Enum

The ScForecastMethod indicates type of forecast for specific consumption, primarily in the CTS sector.

endemo2.data_structures.nuts_tree module

This module contains everything one needs to represent NUTS regions as a tree structure. The leafs are NUTS2 regions, the root is the 2-letter country code and the in-between-nodes are for navigation.

class NutsRegion(region_name)[source]

Bases: object

Represents one NUTS Region according to individual codes.

Parameters:

region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE, DE1, DE11, …

Variables:

region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE, DE1, DE11, …

class NutsRegionLeaf(region_name, data)[source]

Bases: NutsRegion

Represents one NUTS2 Region according to individual codes. It is the leaf of the NUTS tree.

Parameters:

  • region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE11, DE12 …

  • data (Any) – The timeseries for the value the tree is associated with. This can be any type of data.

Variables:

  • region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE11, DE12 …

  • data (Any) – The timeseries for the value the tree is associated with. This can be any type of data.

get()[source]

Getter for the leaf’s data.

class NutsRegionNode(region_name)[source]

Bases: NutsRegion

Represents one NUTS Region according to individual codes. Not a NUTS2 region, but a node in the tree.

Parameters:

region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE, DE1, DE2, …

Variables:

  • region_name (str) – The NUTS tag of the region. For example: DE, DE1, DE2, …

  • _subregions (dict[str, NutsRegion]) – The child regions, accessible per NUTS tag. For DE: {DE1 -> .., DE2 -> ..}

add_leaf_region(nuts2region_obj)[source]

Traverses the NUTS Tree recursively to insert a leaf node.

Parameters:

nuts2region_obj (NutsRegionLeaf) – The NutsRegionLeaf object to insert into the tree

Return type:

None

get_all_leaf_nodes()[source]

Get a list of all leaf nodes.

Return type:

list[NutsRegionLeaf]

Returns:

The list of leaf nodes.

get_nodes_dfs()[source]

Get a list of all nodes in Depth-First-Search order. Used mostly for debugging purposes.

Return type:

list[NutsRegion]

Returns:

The list of nodes in DFS-order.

get_region_name()[source]

Getter for the region_name.

get_specific_node(region_code)[source]

Traverse tree and find the node with region code.

Parameters:

region_code (str) – The region code of the node to find.

Return type:

NutsRegion

Returns:

The NutsRegion object of the region with region_code.

endemo2.data_structures.prediction_models module

This module contains all classes directly representing in data series and prognosis calculations.

class Coef[source]

Bases: object

The container for the coefficients of different forecast methods.

Variables:

  • _exp ((Datapoint, r)) – (x0, y0) is the start point for the exponential calculation and r is the growth rate. Used for calculation y(x) = y0 * (1+r)^(x - x0)

  • _lin ((k0, k1)) – Used for the calculation f(x) = k0 + k1 * x

  • _quadr ((k0, k1, k2)) – Used for the calculation f(x) = k0 + k1 * x + k2 * x^2

  • _offset (float) – Additional constant offset.

  • _method (ForecastMethod) – Method used for calculating output.

  • _fixed_forecast_method (bool) – indicates that the method should not be changed anymore for this coefficient object. Example: Is used when setting the exponential forecast method for timeseries with only one data point.

get_exp()[source]

Getter for the exponential coefficient.

Returns:

The exponential execution variables of form ((start_x, start_y), growth_rate)

Return type:

(Datapoint, float)

get_exp_y(target_x)[source]

Returns the y-axis value of the function at the given x according to the exponential method.

Parameters:

target_x – The x_axis value the function should be applied on.

Return type:

Optional[float]

Returns:

The according y-axis value if exponential start point and growth rate is set, otherwise None.

get_function_y(target_x)[source]

Returns the y-axis value of the function at the given x according to the used method.

Parameters:

target_x – The x_axis value the function should be applied on.

Return type:

Optional[float]

Returns:

The according y-axis value if everything of the chosen method (and the method) is set, otherwise None.

class IntervalForecast(progression_data)[source]

Bases: object

The class depicting a given exponential prediction with different growth rates in certain intervals.

Parameters:

  • progression_data (list[Interval, float]) – The input_and_settings progression data given as a list of intervals and their corresponding growth rate. For example [(Interval(start, end), percentage_growth)].

  • progression_data –

Variables:

_interval_changeRate (list[(Interval, float)]) – The same as progression_data, just the growth rate is not in percentage anymore, but percentage/100

get_forecast(target_x, start_point)[source]

Get the prognosis of the y-axis value for a target x-axis value from the manual exponential interval-growth-rate forecast.

\[y=s_x*(1+r_{1})^{(intvl^{(1)}_{b}-s_y)}*(1+r_{2})^{(intvl^{(2)}_{b}-intvl^{(2)}_{a})}*\text{...}*(1+r_{3})^ {(x-intvl^{(3)}_{a})}\]
Parameters:

  • start_point (Datapoint) – The (x, y) Tuple, that is used as the first value for the exponential growth.

  • target_x (float) – The target x-axis value.

Return type:

float

Returns:

The predicted y value at x-axis value x.

class RigidTimeseries(data)[source]

Bases: object

Class representing data that should be taken just like it is. Without interpolation, without coefficients, only the data over time.

Parameters:

data – The timeseries data, where the x-axis is Time and the y-axis is some value over time. Can contain NaN and Inf values.

Variables:

_data ([Datapoint]) – The timeseries data, where the x-axis is Time and the y-axis is some value over time. Filtered to not contain any NaN or Inf values.

get_last_available_data_entry_or_zero()[source]

Returns the last data entry in the timeseries data if present, else 0.0.

Return type:

Datapoint

get_value_at_year(year)[source]

Returns the value of the RigidTimeseries at the given year, if present. If the value is not present, throws an error.

Parameters:

year (int) – The year the value should be taken from.

Return type:

float

Returns:

The value of the timeseries at year.

class Timeseries(data)[source]

Bases: TwoDseries, RigidTimeseries

A class strictly representing a value over time. This usage is a class invariant and the class should not be used in any other way.

Parameters:

data ([Datapoint]) – The timeseries data, where the x-axis is Time and the y-axis is some value over time. Can contain NaN and Inf values.

Variables:

_data ([Datapoint]) – Where the x-axis is Time and the y-axis is some value over time.

add(other_ts)[source]

Add the data of the other_ts to self. Also return a reference to self. When a datapoint is only present in one of the timeseries it is added!

Parameters:

other_ts (Timeseries) – The timeseries, whose data should be added to self.

Return type:

Timeseries

Returns:

A reference to self.

append_others_data(other_ts)[source]

Append all data of another timeseries to self and return self. Timeseries also sorts the result, so it can remain a valid timeseries.

Parameters:

other_ts (Timeseries) – The timeseries, whose data should be appended.

Return type:

Timeseries

Returns:

self

classmethod fill_empty_years_with_value(ts, interval, fill_value)[source]

Create a timeseries that has data for each year in interval. Take value from given timeseries if present, else fill with given value.

Parameters:

  • ts (Timeseries) – The given timeseries, which values are copied.

  • interval (Interval) – The interval in which data has to be present for every year.

  • fill_value (float) – Value with which gaps in the data should be filled.

Return type:

Timeseries

Returns:

The created timeseries with values from ts and filled gaps with given value.

fill_own_empty_years_with_value(interval, fill_value)[source]

Fill own data in interval with fill value

Parameters:

  • interval (Interval) – The interval that should be filled.

  • fill_value (float) – The value that should be used to fill gaps

  • function – The function that is applied. Should be of form lambda x y1 y2 -> …

Return type:

Any

Returns:

classmethod merge_two_timeseries(t1, t2)[source]

Merge the two Timeseries on the condition that the year is the same. Note: The result is not a Timeseries!

Parameters:

  • t1 (Timeseries) – Timeseries to zip t1 [(a,b)]

  • t2 (Timeseries) – Timeseries to zip t2 [(c, d)]

Return type:

TwoDseries

Returns:

The zipped TwoDseries in format [(b, d)] for where a == c.

class TwoDseries(data)[source]

Bases: object

A class representing a data series [(x, y)]. Both axis can be any type of data.

Parameters:

data ([Datapoint]) – The TwoDseries data, where the x-axis and the y-axis can be any floating point values. Can contain NaN and Inf values.

Variables:

  • _data ([Datapoint]) – Where the x-axis is first in tuple and the y-axis is second.

  • coefficients (Coef) – The coefficients for this data series.

append_others_data(other_tds)[source]

Append all data of another timeseries to self and return self.

Parameters:

other_tds (TwoDseries) – The TwoDseries, whose data should be appended.

Return type:

TwoDseries

Returns:

self

Generate and save the coefficients of all regression methods.

The generated Coefficient object.

bool

Module contents

This package holds all modules that can be reused in very different contexts, therefore being data_structures.
